abstract: This chapter considers the law of "non-delegable duties" (that is, when and how a principal can be held liable for torts committed by a contractor, as opposed to an employee) and describes how the law of Australia is similar to, or differs from, the law of the UK. It suggests that Australian law should be move to allow for NDD liability even in relation to intentional torts, a position which would assist appropriate civil action by sexual abuse victims against religious bodies.
title: Convergence and Divergence: the Law of Non-delegable Duties in Australia and the United Kingdom
subject: law
